Its co-polyester with ethylene glycol has excellent performance in terms of thermal and mechanical properties. Herein, an Au/CeO2-rod catalyst with rich oxygen vacancies was developed to achieve the efficient oxidation of 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF) to FDCA with a 92 % yield under mild conditions, with the addition of 4 equivalents of Na2CO3 at 80℃ under 2 MPa O2 for 6 h. The large specific surface area of CeO2-rod is beneficial for better dispersion of Au nanoparticles. Meanwhile, the high activity of Au/CeO2-rod can be attributed to that the rod-shaped CeO2 exposed more active (100) facets, resulting in strong metal-support interaction between Au nanoparticles and CeO2-rod. This could generate more Au species with oxidized state and more oxygen vacancies, thus promoting the reactant adsorption and oxygen activation and enhancing the final oxidation activity. The oxidation of 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid to FDCA was determined as the rate-determining step in the oxidation of BHMF over the Au/CeO2 catalyst. Graphical Abstract Keywords Biomass 2,5-furan dicarboxylic acid 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan Catalytic oxidation Au/CeO2 Data availability The authors are unable or have chosen not to specify which data has been used. 1 Introduction Polyesters containing 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) units have gained wide attention from worldwide academia and industry in the past decades. A series of furan-based macromolecules can be synthesized by substituting petroleum-based terephthalic acid, which have great application potential in bio-based engineering plastics, bio-based fibers and bio-based packaging materials. FDCA has a rigid ring similar to the phenyl ring in terephthalic acid. Co-polyester of FDCA with ethylene glycol, poly(ethylene glycol) furyl dicarboxylic acid, bears rigidity, abrasion resistance, flexibility and toughness, of which the overall performance is comparable to that of poly(ethylene glycol) terephthalate (polyethylene terephthalate, PET), so that it can be applied in bio-based engineering plastics and bio-based packaging materials. In addition, the higher electron density of the furan ring compared to the phenyl ring makes furan-based polyesters more unstable than conventional terephthalic acid-based polyesters under certain conditions. Therefore, FDCA is potentially applicable in biodegradable plastics [1]. Currently, the mainstream route for the synthesis of 2,5-FDCA is using cellulose as raw materials to obtain the furan-based platform compound 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) via hydrolysis, isomerization, and dehydration, followed by the oxidation of HMF to obtain FDCA [2]. However, the relevant research was restricted by the instability and high price of 5-HMF [3]. In particular, in order to accelerate the oxidation and avoid the covering of FDCA on active sites of catalysts, the oxidation of 5-HMF is usually performed in an alkaline medium, where 5-HMF itself is prone to decomposition. Li et al. [4] found that in a blank experiment the conversion of HMF was 59.6 % in an alkaline medium (pH = 13.3) at 60 ℃ after 1 h. Alternatively, 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF), derived from the reduction of 5-HMF, has good stability under strong alkaline conditions. There is almost no degradation or decomposition under the alkaline conditions at 60 °C after 1 h. Furthermore, BHMF, bearing two hydroxymethyl groups, has high structural symmetry and intermolecular hydrogen bond, resulting in a relatively higher melting point (76–78 ℃ for BHMF [5] versus 30 ℃ for 5-HMF [6]). This makes it convenient to recrystallize and purify BHMF in addition to preservation and transportation. Therefore, synthesis of FDCA from BHMF instead of 5-HMF is technically and economically feasible. With regards to the aerobic oxidation of alcohols, various Au catalysts supported on basic supports have been reported recently [7]. Kaneda et al. [8] demonstrated the importance of support alkalinity for Au nanoparticles in the aerobic oxidation of α-phenyl ethanol to acetophenone and the highest yield of acetophenone was achieved on Au nanoparticles supported on hydrotalcite and MgO. Liu et al. [9,10] ascribed the excellent α-phenyl ethanol oxidation activity obtained with Au nanoparticles loaded on Cr-containing hydrotalcite to the metal-support interaction induced by Cr3+/Cr6+ redox cycle at the interface of Au and Cr-containing hydrotalcite. Santra et al. [11] found that Au nanoparticles supported on Bi doped CeO2 exhibited very high catalytic oxidation ability of alcohols. They suggest that the doping of Bi3+ to CeO2 effectively increases the concentration of surface oxygen vacancy and alkalinity of CeO2. It is generally accepted that various facets of CeO2 have different abilities for oxygen activation, and thus the oxygen adsorption ability decreases in the order of (111) > (110) > (100). Hence, exposure of more (100) and (110) facets will leave more oxygen vacancies, which can be used as nucleation sites for noble metals or as adsorption sites for active oxygen species in the oxidation [12]. As for the preparation of CeO2, there are more methods such as thermal decomposition [13], template method [14], sol-gel method [15], precipitation method [16], hydrothermal method [17–19], solvothermal method [20], among which hydrothermal and solvothermal methods are more capable of preparing CeO2 with special morphology to expose specific facets. Related works have investigated the effect of Au/CeO2 morphology on the oxidation of HMF [21]. However, due to the inherent structural difference between HMF and 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan, their catalytic behaviors are quite different. Herein, CeO2 with rod-shaped, cubic and octahedral morphologies was prepared for loading Au nanoparticles for the oxidation of BHMF to FDCA. As a result, Au nanoparticles supported on rod-shaped CeO2 (Au/CeO2-rod) was proved to be most efficient in the aqueous-phase aerobic oxidation of BHMF to FDCA. The influence of CeO2 morphology on the catalytic performance of Au/CeO2 was investigated thoroughly and the oxidation pathway of BHMF over the Au/CeO2 catalysts was also proposed. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Optimization of reaction parameters for the aqueous-phase aerobic oxidation of BHMF to FDCA In order to determine the reaction parameters for the aqueous-phase aerobic oxidation of BHMF to FDCA, an Au/Comm-CeO2 catalyst was prepared by a deposition-precipitation (DP) method using commercially available CeO2 as the support for Au nanoparticles. Reaction temperature, reaction time, oxygen pressure and base additives were screened in detail firstly for the aqueous-phase aerobic oxidation of BHMF to FDCA using the Au/Comm-CeO2 catalyst aforementioned as the catalyst (Table S1). As displayed in Fig. 1a, the addition of a base additive can greatly promote the oxidation of BHMF, probably due to participation of -OH in the hydration of the aldehyde group to kainediol intermediate, and the increasing -OH concentration in water facilitates faster oxidation of aldehyde-containing intermediates. Meanwhile, the stronger the alkalinity of base additives, the better the promotion efficiency which is consistent with the literature [22], but too much strong alkalinity of base additives may lead to the reduction of carbon balance, mainly due to the fact that aldehydes are prone to disproportionation or to other side reactions under the strong alkaline conditions. When 4 equivalent of Na2CO3 was introduced, the oxidation of BHMF obtained the highest yield of FDCA (92.2 %). Appropriate reaction time is conducive to enhance the selectivity of FDCA. The intermediates were gradually converted to FDCA within 6 h (Fig. 1b), but further prolonging the reaction time caused the decarboxylation of FDCA and its salts. Additionally, the decarboxylation of FDCA occurs easily at higher temperatures, thus lowering the reaction temperature can effectively reduce the possibility of decarboxylation of FDCA. However, the rate of oxidation was reduced at lower temperatures correspondingly (Fig. 1c). Therefore, it is crucial to optimize the reaction temperature when taking into account the reaction rate and FDCA selectivity simultaneously. Moreover, in order to achieve the oxidation of BHMF at lower temperatures, O2 pressure was modulated to accelerate the reaction (Fig. 1d). Obviously, only a slight increase in the yield of FDCA was observed with the increase in O2 pressure. This can be interpreted by the fact that water molecules are the virtual oxygen source in products, while molecular oxygen is used to scavenge the electrons deposited on the surface of Au nanoparticles to form hydroxyl to complete the catalytic cycle. Consequently, FDCA could be obtained in high yield (∼92 %) under the optimal reaction conditions, such as at 60 ℃ for 12 h or at 80 ℃ for 6 h under 2 MPa O2 with 4 equivalents of Na2CO3 as the base additive. For clarity, the detailed data are also listed in Table S1. 2.2 Screening of supports for Au-based catalysts applied for the oxidation of BHMF to FDCA A series of Au-based catalysts supported on different materials were prepared using the DP method and applied for the oxidation of BHMF to FDCA at 80 °C for 6 h ( Fig. 2). Clearly, for Au catalysts supported on materials containing basicity, such as MgO and La2O3 (Fig. 2), good selectivity to FDCA (68–81 %) were achieved. The basicity of the supports obviously contributes to the oxidation of the aldehyde group, but it can be compensated by the alkali additives. It is generally believed that active sites can be occupied by FDCA due to the fact that its acidity and supports can be even etched, resulting in dissolution of supports or leaching of supported metal [23]. Au catalysts supported on other materials, such as carbon, molecular sieves, alumina and silica, showed poor performance in the oxidation of BHMF to FDCA (Fig. 2). The possible reason for the low catalytic activity of Au/SiO2 may be the low isoelectric point of SiO2 (around 2.0). During the deposition and precipitation process, the negative charges are not conducive to the adsorption of Au(OH)nC14-n species on SiO2 surface. Thus, it is difficult to prepare stable small-sized Au nanoparticles, whereas for the Au-based catalysts, there is an obvious relationship between the size of Au nanoparticles and the activity, that is, when the average particle size of Au nanoparticles is smaller than 5 nm, the Au catalyst is more active. As a result, the catalytic activity of Au/SiO2 is poor owing to larger Au particle size [24]. To our delight, Au catalysts supported on Comm-CeO2 with rich oxygen vacancies showed the highest FDCA yield (92.2 %) (Fig. 2). The extraordinary property of the Au/CeO2 catalyst can be explained in two ways: (1) the Ce4+/Ce3+ redox pairs in CeO2 can be interconverted to release or accept oxygen species with a high oxygen storage capacity; (2) strong metal-support interactions between CeO2 and Au nanoparticles leads to electron transfer between Au nanoparticles and CeO2, which further enhances the oxidation ability of Au nanoparticles and thus the oxygen vacancy concentration of CeO2. Additionally, CeO2 supported catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic performance in many oxidation reactions, and thus CeO2 is selected as the suitable support for Au nanoparticles in the following studies. 2.3 Screening of CeO2 morphology for the oxidation of BHMF to FDCA over Au/CeO2 As mentioned above, the exposed facets of CeO2 will be strongly influenced by the preparation methods. Subsequently, the Au/CeO2 catalyst was prepared by sol-gel, precipitation, and hydrothermal methods, respectively, and then applied to the oxidation of BHMF to FDCA. In order to better compare the influence of CeO2 morphology on the oxidation of BHMF to FDCA with Au/CeO2 catalysts, the reaction was generally conducted at 80 ℃ for 3 h. The detailed results are summarized in Table 1. Clearly, Au catalysts supported on CeO2 with various morphologies showed rather different catalytic performances. The Au catalyst supported on rod-shaped CeO2 was more selective than that supported on CeO2 with cubic or octahedral morphologies (entries 4–6, Table 1). Subsequently, the differences in the activity originated from Au catalysts supported on CeO2 with different morphologies will be further explored through detailed characterization techniques. 2.4 Catalyst characterization and structure-property relationship Firstly, CeO2 with different morphologies was characterized by XRD ( Fig. 3). Three types of CeO2 showed the characteristic diffractions at 28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.3°, 59.1°, 69.4°, 76.7°, and 79.1°, corresponding to (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), and (420) facets of CeO2 with a cubic fluorite structure, respectively (PDF#43-1002). Then, Au catalysts supported on CeO2 with different morphologies were also characterized by XRD (Fig. 3). The diffraction lines assignable to CeO2 did not shift, but the diffraction intensity became stronger, probably due to slight enlargement of the CeO2 grains after calcination and reduction. In addition, no characteristic diffraction lines attributable to Au nanoparticles were observed, a hint of uniform and high dispersion of Au nanoparticles. Secondly, the morphology of CeO2 prepared by different methods was characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM), respectively ( Fig. 4). Apparently, rod-shaped CeO2, cubic CeO2 and octahedral CeO2 were successfully prepared via the hydrothermal method. Moreover, the CeO2-rod had a length of about 300–600 nm and a width of about 10 nm. For CeO2-cubes, the width was about 60 nm although a few of them have a width of about 200 nm. By comparison, the CeO2-octahedron had a more uniform size of about 50–80 nm. Furthermore, the interplanar spacing of CeO2 was calculated based on the HRTEM images. The (100) facets (d = 0.27 nm) along the long-axis and (111) facets (d = 0.31 nm) grown in the transverse-axis were predominantly exposed for CeO2-rod. As for CeO2-cube, (111) facets were exposed. With regards to CeO2-octahedron, the main exposed facets were also (111) planes with a small amount of (110) planes (d = 0.19 nm) [25]. After loading Au nanoparticles, the morphology of CeO2 retained well and the average sizes of Au nanoparticles for Au/CeO2 catalysts were 5.2 nm (Au/CeO2-rod), 6.9 nm (Au/CeO2-oct) and 22.0 nm (Au/CeO2-cube), respectively ( Fig. 5). This is because the different exposed facets of CeO2 can affect the Au particles size through different surface energies [26,27]. The physicochemical properties of CeO2 were also characterized using N2 sorption (Fig. S1). Three kinds of CeO2 all showed type IV isotherms and type H3 hysteresis loops, indicating that three kinds of CeO2 contained mesoporous structures. Accordingly, the average pore sizes of CeO2 were calculated and listed in Table 2. The specific surface area (SBET) of three kinds of CeO2 varied greatly although the pore sizes were comparable (33.2–50.7 nm). CeO2-cube had the smallest SBET of only 10.6 m2g−1. CeO2-rod had the largest SBET of 78.1 m2g−1, which is more than three times of that for CeO2-oct (25.4 m2 g−1). Therefore, Au nanoparticles could be dispersed well on the surface of CeO2-rod due to its large specific surface area. As well known, the activity of catalyst is closely related to the valence of Au species. In order to deeply understand the influence of CeO2 morphology on the resultant catalytic activity of Au/CeO2 catalysts, three types of CeO2 and the corresponding Au/CeO2 catalysts were characterized by XPS. From the XPS spectra of Au4f ( Fig. 6), the characteristic peaks attributed to Au 4f7/2 were observed at 83.4–83.8 eV, 84.3–85.2 eV, and 85.6–86.3 eV, respectively, which corresponded to Au0, Au+, and Au3+ species in turn, and the characteristic peaks attributed to Au 4f5/2 were observed at 87.1–87.4 eV, 87.9–88.8 eV, and 89.2–90.0 eV, respectively [28,29]. According to the quantitative calculations of the relative contents of Au0, Au+, and Au3+ species, ca. 18 % of Au was present in the oxidized state (with 11 % Au+ and 7 % Au3+) on the Au/CeO2-rod catalyst surface, higher than those on Au/CeO2-cube (with 9 % Au+ and 6 % Au3+) and Au/CeO2-oct (with 6 % Au+ and 4 % Au3+) (Fig. 6d). In particular, Au3+ species, representing a strong oxidizing ability, was 2.5 times more abundant on Au/CeO2-rod than on the other two catalysts, which may result in the higher catalytic oxidation activity of the Au/CeO2-rod catalyst for the oxidation of BHMF to FDCA (entries 4–6, Table 1). To explain the reason for the higher Au3+ content on Au/CeO2-rod, the Ce3d XPS spectra for CeO2-rod and the supported Au catalyst were further investigated ( Fig. 7a). After deconvolution, the characteristic peaks attributed to Ce 3d5/2 were observed at 879.5–880.0, 881.8–882.2, 884.4–885.1, 888.4–888.6, and 895.5–896.4 eV, respectively and were denoted correspondingly as v0, v, v ', v'', v''', respectively. Accordingly, characteristic peaks attributed to Ce 3d3/2 were observed at 897.7–898.2, 900.3–900.7, 902.5–903.4, 906.8–906.9, and 916.0–916.5 eV, and were denoted as u0, u, u', u'' ', u''' [30,31]. Four peaks, v0, v', u0 and u′, were attributed to Ce3+, while other six peaks, v, v'', v′'', u, u'', and u′'', were attributed to Ce4+, and thus the content of Ce3+ was calculated using the following equation [32]: Ce 3 + % = Ce 3 + Ce 3 + + Ce 4 + = v 0 + v ′ + u 0 + u ′ v 0 + v ′ + u 0 + u ′ + v + v ′ ′ + v ′ ′ ′ + u + u ′ ′ + u ′ ′ ′ As a result, the content of Ce3+ in CeO2-rod was 30.4 %, while the proportion of Ce3+ in Au/CeO2-rod increased to 37.5 % after loading of Au nanoparticles. The increase in the proportion of Ce3+ can be attributed to the existence of a strong metal-support interaction between Au and CeO2-rod. Au transferred some electrons to Ce4+ to form Ce3+, and simultaneously Au atoms were oxidized to Au+ or Au3+, which is consistent with the XPS spectra of Au 4f. As already discussed above, three types of CeO2 with different morphologies displayed the cubic fluorite structure, so when Ce4+ changed to Ce3+, there must be a decrease in lattice oxygen to maintain the overall electroneutrality, leading to more oxygen vacancies [33,34]. To verify this hypothesis, the O1s XPS spectra of CeO2-rod and Au/CeO2-rod were analyzed (Fig. 7b). According to the literature, the peaks at 528.8–529.2, 529.7–530.9 and 532.2–532.9 eV were attributed to lattice oxygen (Olatt), oxygen defects (Ov), surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads) and hydroxyl oxygen (OOH), respectively [32,35,36]. By calculating the relative content of Ov (Ov/(Ov + Olatt + OOH)), the content of Ov slightly increased after loading Au (33.0 % versus 13.8 %), which agrees well with our hypothesis. Oxygen vacancies can adsorb and activate O2 during the reaction, and the reactive oxygen species close to Au nanoparticles will rapidly migrate to the interface of Au-CeO2 to participate in the reaction. Therefore, the concentration of oxygen vacancies on CeO2 with different morphologies will affect the catalytic activity of Au/CeO2. To characterize oxygen vacancies of three types of CeO2 and Au/CeO2 catalysts, Raman spectroscopy was adopted ( Fig. 8) [37]. A very strong Raman band at 465 cm−1 is attributed to the symmetric Ce-O stretching vibration F2g around Ce4+ [38,39]. A small band at 595 cm−1, assigned to a defect due to the presence of Ce3+, was referred as the defect-induced (D) mode. The Raman peaks at 258 and 1180 cm−1 were attributed to the second-order transverse optical (2TA) and the second-order longitudinal optical (2LO) modes, respectively. The content of oxygen vacancy can be estimated by the ratio of the D peak area to the intrinsic peak area of CeO2 (i.e., ID/IF2g) in a semi-quantitative manner [40,41]. Quantitatively, the oxygen vacancy content of Au/CeO2 increased more significantly compared to that before Au loading according to the calculation results, further proving the existence of strong metal-support interactions between Au and CeO2, in good agreement with the XPS characterization results. 2.5 Exploration of reaction mechanism for oxidation of BHMF to FDCA over Au/CeO2-rod In order to reveal the reaction mechanism of the oxidation process of BHMF on Au/CeO2-rod, the kinetic behaviors about the evolution and distribution of products was investigated ( Fig. 9a). BHMF underwent rapid conversion initially to form 5-HMF after one hydroxymethyl group was oxidized to an aldehyde group. After that, the aldehyde group was further oxidized to a carboxyl group to form HMFCA (5-hydroxymethyl-furan-2-carboxylic acid). Subsequently, the other hydroxymethyl group of HMFCA was oxidized to FFCA (5-formylfuran-2-carboxylic acid), followed by the further oxidation of FFCA to FDCA. In the oxidation of 5-HMF, it is generally believed that the oxidation of FFCA to FDCA is the rate-determining-step (RDS), due to that the electron-withdraw property of the carboxyl and aldehyde groups makes the electron density of the furan ring decrease and thus reduces the reactivity of FFCA [39]. However, the main intermediate in the oxidation of BHMF with the Au/CeO2 catalyst was HMFCA, while the concentration of FFCA was kept at a low level (< 1.5 %) in this case, indicating that the oxidation of FFCA to FDCA was a fast step because the Au/CeO2 catalyst can effectively activate the aldehyde group and oxidize it to carboxyl group, thus the RDS was the oxidation of HMFCA to FFCA. In a further step, we analyzed the relationship between the available gold surface area, oxygen vacancy content, and reactivity ( Fig. 10). The results shows that the catalytic performance for three catalysts follows the decreasing trend: Au/CeO2-rod > Au/CeO2-oct > Au/CeO2-cube, which shows a linear correlation between the relative content of oxygen vacancies as well as available gold surface area and the reaction rate. This indicates both the oxygen vacancies from the specific support morphology and the available gold surface areas contribute to the enhanced activity on Au/CeO2-rod. In combination with the kinetic data, the reaction pathway for the Au/CeO2-catalyzed oxidation of BHMF was determined to be BHMF → HMF → HMFCA → FFCA → FDCA (Fig. 9b). This is consistent with the literature that HMF with Au catalysis tends to form HMFCA intermediates which are then oxidized to FFCA [42–45]. Accordingly, a possible oxidation mechanism of BHMF on Au/CeO2 was proposed ( Fig. 11). In the first step, 2,5-BHMF was adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies on CeO2 and thus activated. Meanwhile, molecular oxygen was activated by Au nanoparticles in the oxidation state. The reactive oxygen species and OH- in solution seized the H atoms at the α-C and the hydrogen atoms at the hydroxyl group, respectively, to form aldehyde group. The by-product OH- compensated for the consumption of OH- in the solution. In the second step, 5-HMF formed in the first step still adsorbed on the oxygen vacancy and underwent the further oxidation: the aldehyde C atom was attacked by OH- in the solution to form the keteneglycol alkoxide intermediate, and then the H atoms at the α-C were seized by the reactive oxygen species to form the carboxyl group. Thus, the hydroxymethyl group on the one side of the furan ring was completely oxidized to the carboxyl group. After the intermediate HMFCA was desorbed from the catalyst surface, the other hydroxymethyl group was again adsorbed and activated at the oxygen vacancies, and FDCA was finally obtained after a similar oxidation process. According to the proposed mechanism, the aldehyde intermediates remain adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies rather than being desorbed, and then undergoes a second-step oxidation, which is consistent with the experimental phenomena that HMFCA was predominantly detected as the reaction intermediates in kinetic studies. The RDS in the oxidation of BHMF with the Au/CeO2 catalyst in this case is HMFCA → FFCA, whereas the increase in Au+ and Au3+ content improves the concentration of reactive oxygen species and promotes the seizure of H atoms at α-C. This well explains the positive correlation between the catalytic activity and the content of Au+/Au3+. The Au/CeO2-rod catalyst has the highest content of Au+/Au3+, so that the best catalytic activity in the oxidation of BHMF to FDCA was afforded under the same conditions. 3 Conclusion In summary, we developed an oxygen-vacancy-rich Au/CeO2-rod catalyst to realize the efficient oxidation of BHMF to FDCA. FDCA with a 92 % yield was achieved with the Au/CeO2-rod catalyst, with the addition of 4 equivalents of NaHCO3 at 80 ℃ and 2 MPa O2 for 6 h. The process is performed using molecular oxygen as the oxidant under mild conditions with high efficiency, which is proved to be a green and atomically-economical new strategy for the synthesis of FDCA. It was demonstrated that the support had a significant effect on the oxidation of BHMF. The Au/CeO2-rod catalyst showed much better performance than those Au catalysts supported on CeO2 with cubic or octahedral morphologies. The high activity of Au/CeO2-rod can be attributed to the growth of CeO2-rod along the specific facets to expose more active (100) facets, resulting in strong metal-support interaction between Au nanoparticles and CeO2-rod to generate more oxidized Au species and oxygen vacancies. coredata.dc:description: 2,5-Furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), a bio-based diacid with a rigid ring, has a similar structure to petroleum-based terephthalic acid. Its co-polyester with ethylene glycol has excellent performance in terms of thermal and mechanical properties. Herein, an Au/CeO2-rod catalyst with rich oxygen vacancies was developed to achieve the efficient oxidation of 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF) to FDCA with a 92 % yield under mild conditions, with the addition of 4 equivalents of Na2CO3 at 80℃ under 2 MPa O2 for 6 h. The large specific surface area of CeO2-rod is beneficial for better dispersion of Au nanoparticles. Meanwhile, the high activity of Au/CeO2-rod can be attributed to that the rod-shaped CeO2 exposed more active (100) facets, resulting in strong metal-support interaction between Au nanoparticles and CeO2-rod. This could generate more Au species with oxidized state and more oxygen vacancies, thus promoting the reactant adsorption and oxygen activation and enhancing the final oxidation activity. The oxidation of 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid to FDCA was determined as the rate-determining step in the oxidation of BHMF over the Au/CeO2 catalyst.
